componenttext: I think that we've heard -- we have some information, but we don't have full information. And I think that now that an arbitration has been filed between us to try and determine our respective rights, we just believe that it is inappropriate for us to provide additional comments at this time. Our commercial business activities and relationship is continuing as in the past, and we are looking to just get a third-party determination for the correct interpretation of our respective rights.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: So Rodney, just as a follow-up, just a quick follow-up on the last question. I mean, maybe if you could take a little bit of a step back and just kind of give your perspective on the relationship that's been evolving with The Coca-Cola Company. Obviously,
componenttext: So Rodney, just as a follow-up, just a quick follow-up on the last question. I mean, maybe if you could take a little bit of a step back and just kind of give your perspective on the relationship that's been evolving with The Coca-Cola Company. Obviously, the Mutant situation didn't also go as well as you were hoping for. So kind of how do you see this changing your relationship with the KO as well as with the Bottlers? So maybe it'd just be helpful to just get your broader perspective. And then more specifically, my other question is just really on the EMEA supply chain issues. I guess I'm just wondering if this is limited to certain countries or if this is really a broader regional issue and whether this is being addressed as we speak, so we get more of a bump-up in sales in the fourth quarter. It seems like we've been having some of these supply chain issues in international markets time to time, so how do we think about, really, more fully addressing the issue broadly?

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's a lot for one question, Judy.
componenttext: That's a lot for one question, Judy.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: A follow-up. One was a follow-up.
componenttext: A follow-up. One was a follow-up.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the relationship with Coke, I think our relationship is good and continues to be good. There is -- Coke, obviously looking at their own portfolio and looking for where they believe they see opportunities and where their own BUs would look to expa
componenttext: Okay. On the relationship with Coke, I think our relationship is good and continues to be good. There is -- Coke, obviously looking at their own portfolio and looking for where they believe they see opportunities and where their own BUs would look to expand their own portfolio. As we indicated in the call, there is an exception for certain products that are in the Coca-Cola brand. And that is, in and of itself, an area that we're looking at. We have a difference of opinion on it. We don't know -- at this point, we don't think it's appropriate for us to speculate on, if that comes to fruition, what effect that might or might not have on our brand. I mean, we continue to be partners with Coca-Cola and with the Bottlers. We continue to have our full range sold by them. And we just don't think that at this point, we would be in a position -- or should be in a position to speculate on what effect that might have. It would just be another product being sold by Coca-Cola Bottlers, but the impact and effect on us would be something, I think, wouldn't be appropriate for us to deal with. We don't believe it will have a material impact on our relationship. We just believe we'll have to manage it in an appropriate way if and when it occurs. On the EMEA supply chain side, I think...

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sorry, Rodney. Maybe I could give additional perspective to Judy or a similar perspective. The relationship with The Coca-Cola Company, I believe, is good. And I'm not a lawyer, so I'm giving the response to you from a business perspective. There's an iss
componenttext: Sorry, Rodney. Maybe I could give additional perspective to Judy or a similar perspective. The relationship with The Coca-Cola Company, I believe, is good. And I'm not a lawyer, so I'm giving the response to you from a business perspective. There's an issue in agreement which we've agreed to go to arbitration civilly and determine what course of action is appropriate. So nothing has changed in the relationship, and the manner in which this situation will be dealt with will be conducted from both parties on a civil basis according to the agreement. So I honestly don't see any changes in the relationship with The Coca-Cola Company.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. All right. On the EMEA supply chain side, this did -- it affected us through a number of plants in different areas, not obviously right through all of the -- there are probably 70 or 80 countries that comprise EMEA. But there were a number of countr
componenttext: Sure. All right. On the EMEA supply chain side, this did -- it affected us through a number of plants in different areas, not obviously right through all of the -- there are probably 70 or 80 countries that comprise EMEA. But there were a number of countries and a number of plants that did have supply issues for a whole host of reasons. We've taken steps to address this. We have appointed a -- we had a period of time when our previous Senior VP of Operations retired, and we were looking for a successor. We have appointed a successor, who's got his feet under his desk, and he's in the job. He's been out in Europe. We have also appointed a new VP of Operations in Europe to give us more hands on deck there. And so we are looking at getting our hands around it. We are in the process of doing it at this point in time. Perhaps you would like to add some color to that?

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think that we've had issues -- remember, it was a very hot summer in Europe, and a lot of the plants were working to capacity and beyond capacity. We've had certain issues, which are being addressed and will be addressed going forward. And the one thing
componenttext: I think that we've had issues -- remember, it was a very hot summer in Europe, and a lot of the plants were working to capacity and beyond capacity. We've had certain issues, which are being addressed and will be addressed going forward. And the one thing that's clear is that our business is growing, which is a good thing, and we have to ensure that we have sufficient capacity and sufficient plants to be able to accommodate our needs.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vivien Azer with Cowen.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vivien Azer with Cowen.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to talk about your U.S. business and, specifically, the transfer, your core Green Monster, where, at least in the Nielsen scanner data that we have, it does appear that there has been a modest softening in terms of the market share decline. S
componenttext: I was hoping to talk about your U.S. business and, specifically, the transfer, your core Green Monster, where, at least in the Nielsen scanner data that we have, it does appear that there has been a modest softening in terms of the market share decline. So can you offer any color on whether there's been a change in your promotional strategy heading into the price increase? Or is this more interaction with new product offerings that are hitting the market? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: If I'm looking at the general market, Monster is continuing to increase its share. The category is growing, and Monster is growing in excess of the market. If I look at regular Monster, as such I'm looking for example at the main channel, which is conveni
componenttext: If I'm looking at the general market, Monster is continuing to increase its share. The category is growing, and Monster is growing in excess of the market. If I look at regular Monster, as such I'm looking for example at the main channel, which is convenience, it's reasonably -- there is still some growth in Monster in that -- in the original core line, in a 16-ounce. And then we have -- obviously, we have additional SKUs with the original Green Monster. So the core brand is continuing to grow. There has been the entry into the market of additional products, primarily probably in what we would maybe call or describe as a performance energy category or a workout fitness energy category or not even really maybe in that category. And they have -- there is some sales on that. There were a number of reasons that those products are sort of starting to gain some traction. But if I look at the sales levels they are still behind the increase in sales. So I think overall, we are getting additional products in the category, but the category itself is continuing to grow.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: So we're still seeing growth, Vivien, in Monster Green. It's continuing to grow. And remember, we've added a number of other SKUs into the portfolio, both juice products and the Ultra range, which is the no-sugar product. So while we are seeing growth in
componenttext: So we're still seeing growth, Vivien, in Monster Green. It's continuing to grow. And remember, we've added a number of other SKUs into the portfolio, both juice products and the Ultra range, which is the no-sugar product. So while we are seeing growth in Monster Green, there has been as well a proliferation of other SKUs within our portfolio.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. And in that side, we've obviously -- on the coffee side, we are continuing to see growth in Java. We've just launched the line extension in Java. We have the Caffe Monster line and Espresso Monster, again, that's continued to grow. On the Ultra line,
componenttext: Yes. And in that side, we've obviously -- on the coffee side, we are continuing to see growth in Java. We've just launched the line extension in Java. We have the Caffe Monster line and Espresso Monster, again, that's continued to grow. On the Ultra line, which is growing, we do have plans to launch an additional Ultra in the spring, which we will -- which will be launched, which is Ultra Paradise. So we are continuing to see growth in the category, and we see additional entrants. Probably, to some extent, we're not sure of the exact measurement at this point in time but do see some increase in incremental sales coming into the category from these new entrants.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: And Monster Green does remain a very important barometer for us.
componenttext: And Monster Green does remain a very important barometer for us.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Astrachan with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Astrachan with Stifel.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: So I'm going to try the Coke thing again. You can answer or not, I guess. My understanding of the exceptions relate to the specific products or specific ingredients, which is in there. So are we talking about a product in similarity to, say, a Kickstart f
componenttext: So I'm going to try the Coke thing again. You can answer or not, I guess. My understanding of the exceptions relate to the specific products or specific ingredients, which is in there. So are we talking about a product in similarity to, say, a Kickstart from the Pepsi system, where it's effectively sort of a competitor but not really? Are they adding some sort of caffeine component to some other beverage, which is in a noncarbonated soft drink? Any sort of color you can give on that, that would be helpful.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Mark, there isn't a limitation on them just adding caffeine. They could have a higher caffeine product. There's no limitation on that. There is -- if you look at the agreement, which is filed, but there are certain ingredients that are -- if used in combi
componenttext: Mark, there isn't a limitation on them just adding caffeine. They could have a higher caffeine product. There's no limitation on that. There is -- if you look at the agreement, which is filed, but there are certain ingredients that are -- if used in combination, obviously, then create a definition -- there is a definition of what an energy drink is. The exception goes back to the Coca-Cola brand, not Sprite, not Kickstart, not any other brand. It's the Coca-Cola brand. And if that -- and there are certain exceptions about what -- because the Coke brand has certain -- otherwise, there would be certain limitations, and there is an exception for that brand. But I think that it's a long explanation. There are different analyses of what that means and what that entitles Coke to do. Under that brand, again, if it was just a question of adding vitamins, well, then Coke would obviously add vitamins. There isn't an issue with that. But where the brand transcends into a product that we perceive positioned as an energy drink, that's where we have a difference of view on the exception. And under the Coke brand, that is really where we are. I think there's not much more we could really add or more color we could give at this point in time. There is a section in the agreement that you guys could look up if you really have that interest. But we're dealing with it with Coke, and we think we will come to a resolution reasonably quickly as to what that exception means and what it -- and how it should be implemented.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: And just to add on that, Mark, what I said earlier, the discussions are very civil and very businesslike, very civil. And it's a question of difference of opinion, which will be resolved in -- per the agreement.
componenttext: And just to add on that, Mark, what I said earlier, the discussions are very civil and very businesslike, very civil. And it's a question of difference of opinion, which will be resolved in -- per the agreement.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Chappell with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Chappell with SunTrust.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit further on the gross margin, both for the kind of the quarter and then going forward with pricing. Trying to understand, as we look -- will this more than offset -- I mean, can you hold gross margins relatively flat going forward? And wh
componenttext: Just a little bit further on the gross margin, both for the kind of the quarter and then going forward with pricing. Trying to understand, as we look -- will this more than offset -- I mean, can you hold gross margins relatively flat going forward? And when I say that, have we seen the full impact of costs in the third quarter? Or do you still have another kind of layer or step up of cost input inflation that kicks in, in fourth quarter and 2019?

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, what's interesting, looking at aluminum and -- the tariffs and the imposition of tariffs were announced way after we had our discussion on this call about gross margins. So we've had this increase in tariff, which has resulted in increase of aluminu
componenttext: Well, what's interesting, looking at aluminum and -- the tariffs and the imposition of tariffs were announced way after we had our discussion on this call about gross margins. So we've had this increase in tariff, which has resulted in increase of aluminum, which is slowly coming off, right? It's not -- it's a slow, very slow process. So we've also had extreme increases in freight-in costs that -- we account for cost of sales, where product is moved to our co-packers or moved to our warehouses. That's all included in cost of sales. So we have that significant cost increases in that regard as well. So we have these cost increases. I think that the quarter that we've just experienced, I'm not seeing further increases in aluminum, and I'm not seeing further increases in freight. However, anything is possible. Having said that, we will have a price increase from November 1. And the other thing for sure is we will continue to have this ASC 606 adjustment, which we didn't have when we first spoke about the gross margin issue earlier this year. So it's kind of a mixed bag with increases and cost increases, which is exactly why we were forced into having a price increase. But I hope that answers your question.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I understand. But I guess it's more of -- do you see any need for further price increases from here?
componenttext: Yes, I think I understand. But I guess it's more of -- do you see any need for further price increases from here?

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, we've announced a price increase in NOS and Full Throttle, which we spoke about on the call. We are proposing a price increase in Canada, which we discussed on the call. And where we are now with regard to price increases, I'm not sure we will -- ha
componenttext: Well, we've announced a price increase in NOS and Full Throttle, which we spoke about on the call. We are proposing a price increase in Canada, which we discussed on the call. And where we are now with regard to price increases, I'm not sure we will -- having -- implementing a price increase in November 1, I'm not sure there's runway to do it again within a short period of time unless costs dramatically and significantly increase from where they are today.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. At this point, we haven't sort of envisaged price increases in other places around the world, but I think that is something we will be evaluating in looking at the markets, the elasticity, where we -- if we can justify price increase. And we'll evalu
componenttext: Yes. At this point, we haven't sort of envisaged price increases in other places around the world, but I think that is something we will be evaluating in looking at the markets, the elasticity, where we -- if we can justify price increase. And we'll evaluate that going early in the new year.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: In the United States, we really are now the market leader. In the various countries around the world, we really price ourselves after Red Bull, in most cases. And we don't want the difference between our pricing and Red Bull's pricing to be significantly
componenttext: In the United States, we really are now the market leader. In the various countries around the world, we really price ourselves after Red Bull, in most cases. And we don't want the difference between our pricing and Red Bull's pricing to be significantly out of whack.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: That ends our Q&A session for today's call. I would now like to turn the call back to Mr. Sacks for any further remarks.
componenttext: That ends our Q&A session for today's call. I would now like to turn the call back to Mr. Sacks for any further remarks.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you. On behalf of the company, we'd like to thank everyone for their continued interest. We continue to believe in the company and our strategy and remain committed to continuing to innovate, develop and differentiate our brands and to expand the co
componenttext:
Thank you. On behalf of the company, we'd like to thank everyone for their continued interest. We continue to believe in the company and our strategy and remain committed to continuing to innovate, develop and differentiate our brands and to expand the company both at home and abroad and, in particular, to expand distribution of our products through the Coca-Cola bottling system internationally. We are also particularly excited by new opportunities we have going forward with the portfolio of energy drink products throughout the world comprised of our Monster Energy brand, together with our strategic brands as well as Hydro, Mutant and, in particular, Predator.
Thank you very much for your attendance.

headline: Monster Beverage Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2018
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This concludes today's program. You may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This concludes today's program. You may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
